Thus it is with Black Rebel Motorcycle ClubÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s seventh album. It does what it does impeccably but they have covered this ground with panache already.
It is, then, an enjoyable album, one their fans will relish, although it could do with sounding scuzzier, dirtier. Often likened to the Jesus & Mary Chain, this is BRMC approaching the "Sidewalking"-era Chain, rough yet polished. Some of the best songs are the heroin-y, sub-Spacemen 3/Spiritualized fare, the soft, drowsy, lo-fi hypno-blues of Ã¢â‚¬Å“Some Kind of GhostÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ or the smeared Gregorian gospel slouch of Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sometimes the LightÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½. They also do, and have always done, a mean line in head-nodding drone-rock, best exemplified here by the pulsing, distorted Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sell ItÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½. The near-nine minute closing Ã¢â‚¬Å“Lose YourselfÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ is also worthy of mention, a slow-blooming narco-ballad that Primal Scream would be proud of.
Black Rebel Motorcycle Club wear rockÃ¢â‚¬â„¢nÃ¢â‚¬â„¢roll clichÃƒÂ© with pride, the leather, the black, the drug references and wearily strived-for enigma, and the lesser songs here are easy to mock as a result. However, while they tread familiar ground, they do so with memorable riffs, and quite enough sonic oomph to retain the attention.
